channel.title: Skill-Learning on Accessible IoT
channel.description: Recent content in Skill-Learning on Accessible IoT

item.title: Pro's Eyes: A Wearable System for Synchronous and Asynchronous Observational Pattern Learning
item.description: Pro’s Eyes is a wearable system that enables observational pattern learning from experts in both synchronous and asynchronous modes. The system captures and analyzes expert behavior patterns, facilitating skill transfer and learning through smart glasses technology.

item.title: A Multimodal Wearable Sensing System for Vocal Muscle Biofeedback in Singing Pitch Training
item.description: This paper presents a multimodal wearable sensing system designed to provide vocal muscle biofeedback during singing pitch training. The system helps users develop better control over their vocal muscles through real-time physiological feedback.

item.title: Exploring Singing Breath: Physiological Insights and Directions for Breath-Aware Augmentation in Mixed Reality Design
item.description: This paper explores the physiological aspects of singing breath control and proposes design directions for breath-aware augmentation in mixed reality. The work provides insights into respiratory patterns during singing and how they can be leveraged for immersive training experiences.

item.title: Introduction of the VCSD Dataset: A Vocal Cords Dataset Using EMG and Ultrasonography for Singing Pitch Skill Recognition
item.description: This paper introduces VCSD (Vocal Cords for Singing Dataset), a novel dataset combining EMG and ultrasonography data for singing pitch skill recognition. The dataset provides a valuable resource for researchers working on vocal training systems and physiological sensing.

item.title: A Novel Sensing Method and Its Empirical Study for Vocal Technique Analysis of Singing Pitch Control: Combining Surface EMG with Ultrasonography
item.description: This paper introduces a novel sensing method that combines surface EMG with ultrasonography to analyze vocal techniques during singing pitch control. The multimodal approach provides deeper insights into the physiological mechanisms of singing and opens new possibilities for vocal training systems.
